etymologies: late 16th century (in the sense ‘fixing, becoming fixed’): alteration (first found in Shakespeare) of obsolete fixure (from late Latin fixura, from Latin figere ‘to fix’), with t inserted on the pattern of mixture

definitions: a piece of equipment or furniture which is fixed in position in a building or vehicle
shortDefinitions: piece of equipment etc. fixed in position

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with fitting (sense 1 of the noun)
definitions: articles attached to a house or land and considered legally part of it so that they normally remain in place when an owner moves

examples.text: the hotel retains many original fixtures and fittings

shortDefinitions: articles attached to and legally part of house etc.

definitions: a person or thing that is established in a particular place or situation

examples.text: palm readers were a fixture in most '40s nightclubs

shortDefinitions: person well established in particular situation etc.

definitions: a sports event that takes place on a particular date

examples.text: the team's last away fixture of the season
